title: 106_s862
content: The "Social Security and Medicare Lock Box Act" establishes protections for the Medicare surplus reserve and Social Security trust funds, ensuring they are not counted towards the budget. Congress reaffirms support for these provisions. The text introduces a Social Security Off-Budget Point of Order and a Medicare Surplus Reserve Point of Order, prohibiting the consideration of budget resolutions that violate specific budget enforcement acts. SEC. 5 introduces a Medicare Surplus Reserve Point of Order in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974, preventing the Senate from considering any budget resolution that would decrease the surplus below the levels of the Medicare surplus reserve. SEC. 6 enforces the Medicare surplus reserve. SEC. 6 enforces the Medicare surplus reserve by prohibiting any decrease in the reserve in fiscal years covered by the budget resolution. SEC. 7 amends subsections of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include additional sections. SEC. 8 adds a Medicare surplus reserve to Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The Medicare surplus reserve amounts for fiscal years 2000 to 2013 are as follows: $0, $3 billion, $26 billion, $15 billion, $21 billion, $35 billion, $63 billion, $68 billion, $72 billion, $73 billion, $70 billion, $73 billion, $70 billion, $66 billion. In fiscal years 2013 and 2014, the Medicare surplus reserve amounts were $66 billion and $52 billion, respectively. These amounts are adjusted annually to extend the solvency of the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund through fiscal year 2027. The Medicare surplus reserve cannot exceed the total baseline surplus in any fiscal year. SEC. 9. PAY-AS-YOU-GO AND DISCRETIONARY CAP EXTENSION. This section enforces certain provisions until legislation is enacted to ensure fiscal solvency of Social Security and Medicare trust funds through fiscal year 2027. It also extends the discretionary spending limit based on the fiscal year 2002 baseline. Upon enactment of this Act, the Committees on the Budget Chairs will adjust budget levels and repeal Section 207 of H. Con. Res. 68 (106th Congress).
